snippet.textDisplay:
So honest question... why is this game liked? I saw a couple of gameplay video, it looks like a simulation game coupled with light fighting elements. Is there more to it?

I might check a complete playthrough to get why it's so praised, but now I don't get it...
snippet.textOriginal:
So honest question... why is this game liked? I saw a couple of gameplay video, it looks like a simulation game coupled with light fighting elements. Is there more to it?

I might check a complete playthrough to get why it's so praised, but now I don't get it...

snippet.textDisplay:
@God Blessed Video 2
Ok, that explains a lot more. FYI I don't even like GTA games, so that may be why I don't particularly find this game appealing. I don't really like simulation-heavy games, and I generally favor gameplay over story, even in RPGs (fighting games aren't my favorite genre either).

I might check out more of it someday though, since so many people treasure this game.

Thanks for the info!
snippet.textOriginal:

I might check out more of it someday though, since so many people treasure this game.

Thanks for the info!

snippet.textDisplay: @C_Clop If you compare it to some games now, like GTA 5, it obviously seems slow and even boring, the thing is back then it was impressive because the world they've created looked so real and alive, I mean, almost each individual people had it's routine and you could find them at various point during a day doing different stuff, also, the story is very intriguing, the combat is Virtua Fighter Style, and the graffics were amazing for 1999.
snippet.textOriginal: @C_Clop If you compare it to some games now, like GTA 5, it obviously seems slow and even boring, the thing is back then it was impressive because the world they've created looked so real and alive, I mean, almost each individual people had it's routine and you could find them at various point during a day doing different stuff, also, the story is very intriguing, the combat is Virtua Fighter Style, and the graffics were amazing for 1999.

@heyjeySigma Eh, not much reason to make another SotC. The story started and ended in that game, simple as that. A sequel would kinda ruin it, in my eyes.

But yes, let's just wait and see what The Last Guardian may have for us.

@heyjeySigma Being a fan of ICO and Shadow of the Colossus, just seeing The Last Guardian EXISTING was enough for me to get hyped. Seriously, I thought that game was gone for good.

snippet.textDisplay:
Wow, this is a really upbeat convenience store song! Kind of like that one Japanese convenience store song that became a meme (except... not really :P)!

I'm glad that Shenmue 3 is happening, and I'm glad its Kickstarter goal was reached! I'm a little sad that no big developer wanted to fund the game itself, but hey... in the end, if we get to finish the story of Shenmue, our wishes are about to be granted.
snippet.textOriginal:
Wow, this is a really upbeat convenience store song! Kind of like that one Japanese convenience store song that became a meme (except... not really :P)!

I'm glad that Shenmue 3 is happening, and I'm glad its Kickstarter goal was reached! I'm a little sad that no big developer wanted to fund the game itself, but hey... in the end, if we get to finish the story of Shenmue, our wishes are about to be granted.

snippet.textDisplay: +MCHellshit tbh I agree in some senses. I liked the game but the QTE idea and gameplay experience was kinda shallow. The combat system seemed interesting with the special attacks and scrolls, but I never felt motivated to dig into it nor did I need to to finish the game. On the flip side, I felt it had the highest level of detail and realism I had ever seen in a game especially for its time (it is one of the most expensive games ever made after all). Its soundtrack was moving. The game world felt more alive than any I had dived into. That said, I think I respect it more as a work of art than a game.
snippet.textOriginal: +MCHellshit tbh I agree in some senses. I liked the game but the QTE idea and gameplay experience was kinda shallow. The combat system seemed interesting with the special attacks and scrolls, but I never felt motivated to dig into it nor did I need to to finish the game. On the flip side, I felt it had the highest level of detail and realism I had ever seen in a game especially for its time (it is one of the most expensive games ever made after all). Its soundtrack was moving. The game world felt more alive than any I had dived into. That said, I think I respect it more as a work of art than a game.

snippet.textDisplay: Shenmue 3 is happening, I simply can't believe it. The 2M$ Kickstarter funding goal was shattered not even 12 hours after it was launched! In the #1600 video, I said I was hoping for a Shenmue 3 since Ryo's story needed closure, but wasn't sure it would ever happen... and here we are. One of my favorite series ever, it helped define my gaming childhood and is one of the main reasons I absolutely want to visit Japan someday. I can't wait. I had to go with the game's most epic and emotional theme for this: Tomato Convenience Store.
snippet.textOriginal: Shenmue 3 is happening, I simply can't believe it. The 2M$ Kickstarter funding goal was shattered not even 12 hours after it was launched! In the #1600 video, I said I was hoping for a Shenmue 3 since Ryo's story needed closure, but wasn't sure it would ever happen... and here we are. One of my favorite series ever, it helped define my gaming childhood and is one of the main reasons I absolutely want to visit Japan someday. I can't wait. I had to go with the game's most epic and emotional theme for this: Tomato Convenience Store.
